CONCLUSION: Preliminary objection dismissed (non-exhaustion of domestic remedies);Violation of Art. 3;Violation of Art. 5-1;Violation of Art. 6-1;Remainder inadmissible;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses partial award
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in PERSON .
CARDINAL . The applicant was arrested on DATE on suspicion of abetting bribery .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG issued an order remanding the applicant in custody for a period of DATE . The court ’s reasoning was the following : “ the suspect has reached the age at which he may be criminally prosecuted , he is suspected of having committed a serious offence and he is unemployed ” .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was indicted inter alia for the offence of aiding and abetting bribery , involving large sums of money , which was punishable by up to twenty years’ imprisonment .

CARDINAL . On DATE , ORG examined a habeas corpus request lodged by the applicant and a request lodged by the prosecutor to prolong the detention . In his habeas corpus request the applicant argued that he was married , had CARDINAL children and was employed . The court dismissed the applicant ’s request but upheld the prosecutor ’s request and prolonged the detention .

CARDINAL . Similar prolongations were ordered up until DATE , when the investigation was completed and the criminal case file was sent by the prosecution to ORG . After DATE , the applicant remained in detention without having his detention warrant prolonged . He submitted numerous habeas corpus requests relying inter alia on his medical condition ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) and on the impossibility of receiving appropriate medical care in prison due to a lack of specialised doctors and medication , but they were all rejected .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant complained inter alia that from DATE he had been detained without any warrant . His request was dismissed .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a habeas corpus request with ORG arguing inter alia that his detention was incompatible with his medical condition due to the lack of appropriate medical care in prison . He asked to be released from detention .
CARDINAL . On DATE Judges PERSON , PERSON and GPE from FAC found the applicant ’s request well - founded and decided to replace the applicant ’s remand in custody with house arrest .
CARDINAL . It appears that at the time of adoption of the present judgment the applicant was still under house arrest .
CARDINAL . From DATE the applicant was detained in FAC . CARDINAL of ORG ( Izolatorul Anchetei Preliminare Nr . CARDINAL ) . On several occasions he was hospitalised in FAC .

CARDINAL . According to medical certificates submitted by the applicant , and not contested by the Government , he suffered from numerous diseases such as chronic hepatitis , second - degree hydronephrosis ( accumulation of urine in the kidney because of an obstruction in the urethra ) , uric diathesis , increased ecogenicity of pancreatic parenchyma , chronic bilateral pyelonephritis ( inflammation of the kidney and pelvis caused by bacterial infection ) with functional impairment of the right kidney , hydronephrosis of the right kidney with functional impairment , stones in the urinary tract , somatoform disorder , chronic renal failure , head trauma and generalised anxiety disorder of hypertensive type .

CARDINAL . On numerous occasions he was prescribed treatment in hospital and even surgery on his right kidney . On DATE and DATE the applicant was consulted by PERSON , an urologist from ORG , a hospital belonging to ORG , who recommended urgent surgery on his right kidney in order to eliminate an obstruction of the urethra . The doctor advised that a delay might result in the degradation of the kidney and its extirpation . A similar recommendation was reiterated on DATE by the Doctor in Chief of ORG , Dr. PERSON , who recommended that the operation be carried out in a specialised urological hospital of ORG . It does not appear from the ORG ’s submissions that this recommendation was ever followed up .
CARDINAL . The Government argued that the applicant was provided with sufficient medical care , but the applicant disputed this .

CARDINAL . The Government submitted numerous reports drawn up by prison doctors stating that the applicant refused to submit to medical checks and treatment and requested to be transferred to a normal hospital . According to some such reports the applicant argued that the treatment in prison was ineffective and that he needed medication which was not available there .
CARDINAL . According to a letter addressed to ORG and to ORG by the prison authorities on DATE , the applicant started a hunger strike to protest against his being treated in the prison .

CARDINAL . On an unspecified date the applicant complained to ORG about the lack of adequate medical treatment . By a letter dated DATE the applicant ’s complaint was rejected and he was informed inter alia that he had had medical checks on CARDINAL occasions by prison doctors and by doctors from outside the prison . He had been offered medical treatment in accordance with the “ modest possibilities ” of the prison medical service and with the medication brought by his relatives . He had been hospitalised in the medical section of the prison on CARDINAL occasions , where he had received adequate medical treatment , and on CARDINAL occasions in FAC .

CARDINAL . The applicant submitted a letter from the Doctor in Chief of ORG addressed to his lawyer , dated DATE , in which it was stated that there were no urologists , cardiologists and neurosurgeons among the doctors of ORG .

CARDINAL . NORP In another letter addressed to the applicant ’s lawyer by the Chief of the Prison where the applicant was detained , dated DATE , the latter was informed that there were no such doctors at the prison either and that in the event of an emergency the applicant would be transferred to ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG initiated criminal proceedings against the applicant and another co - accused on charges of abetting bribery .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG initiated new criminal proceedings against the applicant on charges of fraudulently dispossessing a person of MONEY ( ORG ) .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG initiated new criminal proceedings against the applicant on charges of fraudulent dispossession of CARDINAL persons of their apartments .
CARDINAL . All of the above criminal proceedings were joined in CARDINAL single case file and the criminal investigation lasted until DATE , when ORG sent the criminal file to ORG .
CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE the ORG received the criminal file and a judge was assigned to the case .
CARDINAL . On DATE the judge set DATE as the date of the first hearing .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was unable to come to the hearing due to high blood pressure . He was examined by a doctor who issued him a certificate confirming that the applicant had high blood pressure and was not able to attend the hearing . The hearing was adjourned until DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the hearing did not take place since the prosecutor and CARDINAL of the alleged victims were absent . It was adjourned until DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the hearing was adjourned until DATE due to the absence of CARDINAL of the alleged victims and the applicant ’s lawyers .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant informed the court that he was not feeling well and asked to be hospitalised . The court decided to send the applicant for a medical examination at ORG , a hospital belonging to ORG . The hearing appears to have been adjourned indefinitely .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant complained to the court that the authorities were refusing to send him for a medical examination , and that he had therefore commenced a hunger strike on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the judge assigned to the case wrote to the prison authorities and asked them to comply with the decision of DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant complained to ORG about the non - enforcement of the decision of DATE .

CARDINAL . It appears that on an unspecified date the prison authorities had attempted to take the applicant to ORG , but that he had refused on the ground that the decision of DATE provided for his examination in ORG . The prison authorities informed the judge assigned to the case about the applicant ’s refusal .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant wrote again to the judge informing him that the prison authorities had refused to take him to ORG as provided in the decision of DATE , and as a result his medical condition was becoming worse . He informed the judge that he had no other solution but to go on hunger strike again .
CARDINAL . It appears that DATE the applicant was taken to ORG for examination since the criminal file contains medical documents from ORG dated DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the resumption of the hearings was scheduled . However , the proceedings were adjourned due to the applicant ’s medical condition . The applicant was seen by a doctor , who concluded that he was suffering from the consequences of a brain disease ( consecinţele afecţiunii organice a creierului cu sindrom cerebral astenic ) and noted that he refused the treatment prescribed to him .

CARDINAL . On DATE the prosecutor and CARDINAL of the applicant ’s lawyers were absent . The applicant declared that he was not satisfied with his lawyers and that he wanted to instruct other lawyers . He requested an adjournment . The hearing was adjourned until DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the hearing was adjourned due to the fact that the applicant had not instructed a new lawyer .
CARDINAL . On DATE the hearing was adjourned until DATE at the request of the applicant ’s new lawyer , who intended to present evidence confirming the applicant ’s serious medical condition .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant ’s lawyer presented medical documents and requested that the applicant undertake a psychiatric examination in order to establish his competence to plead to the charges . The request was allowed and a psychiatric examination of the applicant was ordered .
CARDINAL . On DATE a commission of psychiatric doctors concluded that a psychiatric examination would only be possible after the applicant ’s admission to ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE Judge PERSON ordered that the applicant be admitted to ORG in order to carry out the psychiatric examination ordered on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the psychiatric examination was completed and the applicant was found competent to plead to the criminal charges . The medical report was sent to the court on DATE .

DATE . On DATE the applicant asked the court inter alia about the state of the proceedings and was informed on DATE by Judge PERSON that the hearings would be resumed in DATE after the lawyer of the other co - accused had returned from a business trip to GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE a hearing was adjourned until DATE on the ground of the applicant ’s request for a change of lawyer .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant challenged the judge assigned to his case on the ground inter alia that this judge would prolong the examination of the case , would not allow him to undergo surgery on his kidney as recommended by Dr Spânu , would be biased and would reject his habeas corpus requests . The challenge was dismissed and the hearing was adjourned in order to request information from the prison authorities about the applicant ’s medical condition .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant requested an adjournment of the hearing on the ground that he was not feeling well and that he needed medical treatment . The hearing was adjourned until DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was examined by Dr Spânu , an urologist , who prescribed urgent surgery on his kidney ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the hearing was resumed and the court examined and dismissed a habeas corpus request lodged by the applicant who relied mainly on his medical condition . The hearing was then adjourned .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant again challenged the judge on the ground that he refused to allow his release on medical grounds ; the challenge was dismissed . He also asked that an ambulance be called ; this request was also dismissed , the court observing that the applicant was attempting to prolong the criminal proceedings against him . The court also gave the applicant an official warning since he had raised his voice to the judge . The applicant finally dismissed his lawyer and he was given time to sign a contract with another lawyer .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was absent from the hearing on grounds of health and the court adjourned it until DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was absent again and the court adjourned the hearing until DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the prosecutor informed the court that , according to LAW which entered into force on DATE , ORG no longer had jurisdiction to examine the criminal case against the applicant . He requested that the case be transmitted to ORG for examination . The court allowed the Prosecutor ’s request and the criminal file was sent to ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the President of ORG wrote to ORG and asked it to order that the case be transferred to ORG because , inter alia , following the judiciary reform of DATE ORG was the successor instance of ORG which had already started to examine the case .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected the request of the President of ORG and drew her attention to the need to ensure the examination of the case within a reasonable time .

CARDINAL . On DATE a hearing was held for the first time before FAC . The applicant challenged the newly appointed judge , PERSON , on the ground that he would dismiss all his requests . The challenge was dismissed DATE and the hearing was adjourned .
CARDINAL . On DATE the hearing was adjourned until DATE due to the absence of the prosecutor and CARDINAL of the alleged victims .
CARDINAL . On DATE and CARDINAL DATE the hearings were adjourned because the judge was ill .
CARDINAL . On DATE the judge was involved in a conference and the hearing was adjourned until DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the judge was involved in a hearing in an unrelated case and the hearing was adjourned until DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was absent due to his hospitalisation in ORG and the hearing was adjourned until DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the court started to examine the merits of the case by questioning one of the victims . Since other victims and witnesses were absent , the court adjourned the hearing until DATE .

DATE . On DATE the lawyer of the applicant ’s co - accused was absent and the co - accused requested an adjournment . The court decided to adjourn the hearing for DATE in view of the impending judicial vacation .
CARDINAL . On DATE the hearing was adjourned until DATE because Judge PERSON had resigned from his functions .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant complained to ORG about the excessive length of the criminal proceedings against him . He received an answer dated DATE in which he was informed inter alia that the President of ORG had been requested to take all necessary measures to ensure the examination of the case within a reasonable time .
CARDINAL . On DATE the hearing was adjourned until DATE because the same judge , Judge PERSON , was ill .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant dismissed his lawyer and a pro bono lawyer was appointed . The applicant requested to be examined by a medical commission , but his request was dismissed . He unsuccessfully challenged the judges who rejected his request .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant requested that his pro bono lawyer be dismissed on grounds of lack of experience and asked to be examined by a medical commission ; however , his requests were dismissed . CARDINAL of the alleged victims was heard and the hearing was adjourned until DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the court heard a witness and adjourned the hearing until DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant concluded a representation contract with another lawyer and the hearing was adjourned until DATE .
DATE . On DATE the applicant ’s new lawyer was involved in another case and could not attend the hearing . The court adjourned the hearing until DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE and DATE the judge was ill and the hearing was adjourned until DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was hospitalised in ORG and the prosecutor was absent . The hearing was adjourned until DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE there was a change of prosecutors and the new prosecutor requested an adjournment in order to study the case file . The hearing was adjourned until DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the court heard the statements of the applicant and his co - accused in respect of the charges against them . The applicant also submitted that he was ill and was unable to participate in the court hearing . The court adjourned the hearing until DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the court read out the declarations of several witnesses made during the investigation stage of the proceedings . The applicant requested again to be examined by a medical commission , but his request was dismissed and he was warned not to attempt to prolong the examination of the case . The court adjourned the hearing until DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the hearing was adjourned until DATE due to the illness of the judge .
CARDINAL . It appears that DATE and DATE ( the date on which the Government submitted a copy of the criminal case file to ORG ) no hearings took place .
CARDINAL . At the date of the adoption of its judgment the ORG had not been informed by the parties that the criminal proceedings before ORG had been concluded .
CARDINAL . DATE , insofar as relevant , states as follows :

“ ( CARDINAL ) Detention takes place on the basis of a warrant issued by a judge for a maximum period of DATE . The lawfulness of the warrant may be challenged , in accordance with the law , before a hierarchically superior court . The period of detention may be extended only by a court , in accordance with the law , to a maximum period of DATE . ”
CARDINAL . The relevant parts of the old Code of Criminal Procedure , in force until DATE , read as follows :
“ Section CARDINAL . The length of detention on remand and its prolongation

Detention takes place on the basis of a warrant issued by a judge for a maximum period of DATE . The period of detention on remand may be extended ... to a maximum of DATE , while in exceptional cases ... to a maximum period of DATE . The prolongation of the detention shall be ordered by a judge on the basis of a motivated request by the prosecutor .
After the criminal case file has been sent to a court , the accused may be detained until the final resolution of the case , which should take place within a reasonable time . ”
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of the new Code of Criminal Procedure , in force since DATE , read as follows :
Section CARDINAL

“ ( CARDINAL ) Preventive measures may be applied by the prosecuting authority or by the court only in those cases where there are serious grounds for believing that an accused ... will abscond , obstruct the establishment of the truth during the criminal proceedings or re - offend , or they can be applied by the court in order to ensure the enforcement of a sentence .

( CARDINAL ) Detention on remand and alternative preventive measures may be imposed only in cases concerning offences in respect of which the law provides for a custodial sentence exceeding DATE . In cases concerning offences in respect of which the law provides for a custodial sentence of DATE , they may be applied if ... the accused has already committed the acts mentioned in § ( CARDINAL ) .
( CARDINAL ) In deciding on the necessity of applying preventive measures , the prosecuting authority and the court will take into consideration the following additional criteria :
CARDINAL ) NORP the character and degree of harm caused by the offence ,
CARDINAL ) NORP the character of the ... accused ,
CARDINAL ) NORP his / her age and state of health ,
CARDINAL ) NORP his / her occupation ,
CARDINAL ) his / her family status and existence of any dependants ,
CARDINAL ) his / her economic status ,
CARDINAL ) NORP the existence of a permanent place of abode ,
CARDINAL) other essential circumstances .
Section CARDINAL
( CARDINAL ) Detention on remand ... can be applied only on the basis of a court decision ...
Section CARDINAL . Detention on remand
( CARDINAL ) Detention on remand means the detention of the suspect , accused or indicted person in a state of arrest in places and in conditions provided for by law .
( CARDINAL ) Detention on remand may be applied to someone in the circumstances and in the conditions provided for in Article CARDINAL , as well as when :
CARDINAL ) NORP the suspect , the accused or the indicted person does not have a permanent place of residence on the territory of GPE ;
CARDINAL ) NORP the suspect , the accused or the indicted person is unknown ;
CARDINAL ) NORP the suspect , the accused or the indicted person has breached the conditions imposed on him / her concerning other preventive measures .
( CARDINAL ) The decision by which detention on remand is ordered can be challenged by way of an appeal before the hierarchically superior court .
Section CARDINAL . The length of the remand and its prolongation

( CARDINAL ) The duration of a person ’s remand starts to run from the moment of his or her arrest , or , if the person was not arrested , from the moment of enforcement of the court decision ordering the remand . ...

( CARDINAL ) Remand during the investigation stage of the proceedings , before the case file is sent to the competent court [ by the prosecutor ] shall not be longer than DATE , except in cases provided for in the present code . The running of the duration of the remand during the investigation stage of the proceedings ceases on the date when the prosecutor sends the criminal case file to a court and when the detention on remand is revoked or is replaced by another preventive measure which does not involve a deprivation of liberty .
( CARDINAL ) Any prolongation of detention on remand may not be for a period longer than DATE .

( CARDINAL ) If it is necessary to prolong the duration of detention on remand of an accused , the prosecutor shall , not DATE before the expiry of the remand order , make a request in that respect to the investigating judge .

( CARDINAL ) When deciding on the prosecutor ’s request for the prolongation of the remand , the investigating judge , or , as the case may be , the court , has the right to replace detention on remand by home detention , release under judicial control or bail .
( CARDINAL) After the sending of the bill of indictment to a court all requests concerning detention on remand shall be examined by the court in charge of the criminal case .

( CARDINAL ) The prolongation of the duration of remand for DATE shall be decided by the investigating judge on the basis of a request of the district prosecutor . In case of a necessity to prolong the duration of remand for DATE the request shall be lodged by the district prosecutor with the consent of ORG or his deputies .
( CARDINAL ) The decision concerning the prolongation of the detention on remand may be challenged by way of an appeal to the hierarchically superior court .
Section CARDINAL
A person detained on remand under the provisions of LAW may request , at any time during the criminal investigation , his provisional release under judicial control or on bail .
Section CARDINAL . Provisional release under judicial control of a remanded person

( CARDINAL ) ORG provisional release under judicial control of a remanded person , or of a person in respect of whom a request for detention on remand has been made , may be granted by the investigating judge or by a court only in case of offences committed through negligence or intentional offences punishable with DATE of imprisonment .

( CARDINAL ) NORP provisional release under judicial control may not be granted to an accused who has outstanding criminal convictions for serious , very serious or exceptionally serious offences or if there exists information that he or she will commit another offence , will try to influence witnesses , will try to destroy evidence or will abscond .
( CARDINAL ) NORP provisional release under judicial control of a remanded person shall be accompanied by one or more of the following obligations :
CARDINAL ) not to leave the town of residence except in the conditions set by the investigating judge or by the court ;
CARDINAL ) NORP to inform the investigation organ or the court of any change of address ;
CARDINAL ) not to go to certain places ;
CARDINAL ) NORP to appear before the investigation organ or the court when summonsed ;
CARDINAL ) not to make contact with certain persons ;
CARDINAL ) not to commit acts capable of hindering the discovery of the truth ;
CARDINAL ) not to drive cars or exercise any profession of the kind used for committing of the offence .
Section CARDINAL

( CARDINAL ) A preventive measure applied may be replaced by a harsher CARDINAL , if the need for it is proved by evidence , or by a lighter one , if by applying it the proper behaviour of ... the accused is ensured , with the aim of ensuring the normal course of the criminal investigation and of enforcing the sentence imposed .
Section CARDINAL

( CARDINAL ) In examining a case the court , ex - officio or at the request of the parties and having heard their opinion , shall have the power to apply , revoke or discontinue the preventive measure applied to the accused . A new request for the application , replacement or revocation of a preventive measure may be submitted if there are grounds for such a request , but not DATE from the date of entry into force of the last decision in this respect or if new circumstances have arisen .
Section CARDINAL

( CARDINAL ) Within DATE from the date on which the case was distributed for judgment , the judge or the bench , having examined the case - file , shall set a date for the preliminary hearing . The preliminary hearing in cases where the person is arrested shall be held urgently and given priority .
... ( CARDINAL ) At the preliminary hearing the following issues shall be examined :
... CARDINAL ) NORP preventive and protective measures .
Section CARDINAL

... ( CARDINAL ) In setting a date for the examination of the case , the court shall order the maintenance , revocation or discontinuation of preventive measures , in conformity with the present Code . ”

CARDINAL . In GPE v. ORG and ORG ( final judgment of ORG of CARDINAL October CARDINAL ) , DATE after being released from detention on remand , the applicant claimed and obtained compensation in the amount of MONEY ( ORG ) for having been held in inhuman and degrading conditions for DATE . The case was examined by CARDINAL instances , since the judgment of ORG was not challenged before ORG and the overall length of the proceedings was DATE and DATE . The court based its award on ORG and CARDINAL of the Convention .

CARDINAL . In PERSON v. ORG and ORG ( civil judgment of ORG of DATE ) , the applicant was awarded ORG CARDINAL for being subjected to torture by CARDINAL male policemen during the investigation stage of the criminal proceedings against her . The domestic courts based their judgment on a final criminal judgment against the policemen , by which they were found guilty and sentenced for committing acts of torture .

CARDINAL . In the cases of GPE and GPE ( judgments of DATE and of DATE of ORG and of the ORG respectively ) the courts examining habeas corpus requests lodged by the applicants and ordered their release on the basis inter alia of their poor state of health . In particular in the case of PERSON the court stated that “ according to medical certificates and to the applicant ’s medical records , he suffers from an ophthalmologic disease which needs treatment ” . In the case of GPE ORG stated that “ the applicant ’s lengthy detention contributed to the aggravation of some of his diseases ” .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the LAW reads as follows :

“ ( CARDINAL ) A person whose rights are violated by a public authority through an administrative act or through the failure to examine a request within the statutory period , is entitled to obtain the recognition of the right claimed , the annulment of the act and compensation for damage .
( CARDINAL ) The ORG bears pecuniary liability , according to the law , for harm caused through errors committed in criminal proceedings by the investigating authorities and courts . ”
CARDINAL . NORP The relevant provisions of LAW read as follows :
“ Section CARDINAL . Liability of the ORG for damage caused by the actions of the criminal investigation organs , prosecution and courts

( CARDINAL ) Damage caused to a natural person through illegal conviction , illegal prosecution , illegal application of preventive measures in the form of detention on remand or of a written undertaking not to leave the city , and illegal subjection to the administrative sanction of arrest or of non - remunerated community work , is to be fully compensated by the ORG , whether or not officers in the criminal investigation organs , the prosecution or judges were at fault . ... ”
